question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
\emph{Streptococcus viridans} bacteria divide along a preferred axis and
therefore form chains when they divide. You study a population of
\emph{S. viridans} in a blood culture. Let \emph{X} be the length (in
Âµm) of a randomly chosen chain. Its distribution is described by the
probability density function

\[p(x) = \frac1{x}, \quad 1 \leq x \leq e\]

Find the standard deviation of \emph{X}.
sols:
At first we calculate the Variance $Var[X]$.

\begin{align*}
Var[X]=& E[X^2]-(E[X])^2\\
 =& \int_1^ex^2\cdot\frac1xdx - (e-1)^2\\
 =& \int_1^exdx - (e-1)^2\\
 =& \left.\frac{x^2}{2}\right|_1^e - (e-1)^2\\
 =& \frac{e^2}2 - \frac12 - e^2 +2e -1 \\
 =& -\frac{e^2}2+2e-\frac32 \\
 =&  -\frac12(e-3)(e-1)\\
 =& \frac12(3-e)(e-1) \quad (\approx 0.242)
\end{align*}

Then

\[\sigma=\sqrt{\frac12(3-e)(e-1)}\approx0.492\]
hints:
Use the formula for the standard derivation

$\sigma = \sqrt{Var[X]},\quad\text{with}\quad Var[X]=E[X^2] - (E[X])^2.$

Recall from (a) that $E[X] = e-1.$
